awd_titl_txt: FSML:   Acquisition of a Raman Microscope at the Skidaway Institute of Oceanography
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is to purchase and install a confocal Raman microscope (CRM) at the University of Georgia's Skidaway Institute of Oceanography (SkIO). Many of the research problems in marine science involve the study of small particles and organisms. Most current methods for studying small samples require grouping large numbers of individual particles together to obtain enough material for analysis. Pooling samples can obscure critical details of the diversity of particle composition and structure within them. The CRM can obtain chemical compositional data for individual particles smaller than a micron in size, and it can automatically map sample composition over much larger scales in fine detail. The capacity to image both organic and inorganic chemical structure has direct application to the fields of marine microbiology, chemistry, ecology and geology. The presence of a CRM at a southeastern coastal laboratory will allow regional scientists to address new research questions in ocean science. The new analytical capabilities will directly improve the funded activities of 75% of SkIO?s faculty in addition to external, collaborating scientists from the southeastern US and beyond. Additionally, the highly visual output of the CRM will allow educators, citizen-scientists, and the public to better understand the research conducted at SkIO and by visiting scientists.

This proposal seeks funds for the acquisition of a Horiba Jobin Yvon XploRA PLUS Confocal Raman microscope, equipped with 532 nm and 785 nm lasers, motorized and software-controlled XYZ sample stage, an integrated safety shield, and associated autofocus, calibration, particle mapping, chemical identification and statistical analysis software and uninterruptible power supply. The requested instrument will add significant, high-resolution imaging and spectroscopic capability to an existing particle counting and image analysis facility in the coastal Southeastern US, as well as be synergistic with existing trace element, stable isotope, and conventional light microscopy facilities located at the University of Georgia Skidaway Institute of Oceanography (SkIO). The proposed instrument will allow sub-micron chemical characterization, particle mapping, and quantification of complex samples from a wide array of projects and fill an analytical and scientific gap in the region. The requested instrument will allow on-location, low-cost analysis of samples from existing and future projects in several critical areas of marine research, both local and regional. It also will enhance educational opportunities for several established, collaborative, and upcoming programs at SkIO, many of which target under-represented groups. Finally, it will provide highly visual data which is invaluable for educational and outreach efforts. For more information about SkIO, please visit their website at https://www.skio.uga.edu/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

 

Scientific progress is often made using new instrumentation which allows for novel data and analyses to be gathered. This proposal was to fund the acquisition of a confocal Raman microscope, the first such instrument at the Skidaway Institute of Oceanography (SkIO) campus of the University of Georgia. This microscope is designed to use laser light to brightly illuminate a sample, using optics to focus the beam down to a micron in diameter. The Raman effect means that some of this laser light will interact with the molecules being illuminated, be shifted in wavelength by this interaction, and this altered light is then gathered by the microscope?s optics, isolated from the reflected laser light, and analyzed. In practical terms this means that one can obtain a Raman ?fingerprint? of sample composition, again on very small particles or portions of particles. The confocal nature of this instrument means that this data is collected on a small volume of the sample as well, allowing for some 3-D measurements and mapping to also be possible. In the past this type of capability was limited to large, extremely expensive instruments, but advances in Raman technology have allowed for relatively small devices that can be used in marine laboratories.  The instrument has wide application to studies of particle composition, including sediments, aerosols, and pollutants such as microplastics. 

 

The specific instrument funded by this grant was a Horiba-Yvon ExploRA Plus confocal Raman system, with 2 lasers (infrared and green), a cooled high sensitivity detector, integrated optical system, and an Olympus research microscope with an automated xyz stage. This system was installed in a climate-controlled lab with a UPS and backup generator power in case of longer time power outages. This was installed in late February 2020, and has been in operation since that time. Periodic maintenance has been performed under the included service contract. SkIO has advertised the availability of this instrument to the regional scientific community through a web page, seminars and email lists, and has to date hosted visits from Georgia Tech, Georgia State, Savannah State, College of Charleston and NOAA labs Charleston, as from the University of Georgia Athens. 

 

            In terms of Broader Impacts, this instrument was central to the master?s Thesis project of a young female graduate student at the University of Georgia. She is on schedule for her thesis defense in July 2022, and has one paper in prep and another one planned for submission in peer-reviewed journals. Her work focused on microplastic contamination in a local aquarium. Another graduate student from Savannah State University (an HBCU) used the instrument purchased with this grant to gather data that played an integral part of her master?s Thesis, and she defended in April 2021. Her work is also in prep for submission to a peer-reviewed journal. There are additional ongoing collaborations with Savannah State students and scientists (many of whom are underserved minorities) on microplastics research. Finally, a number of undergraduate summer intern projects involved examining microplastic abundances in local river systems. Outreach to the public, although limited because of Covid-related restrictions, involved a YouTube lecture on plastic pollution as well as several Zoom videoconferences with undergraduate and high school students interested in the subject.
